taskGroup.name: Semi Automatic TMA Walkthrough
taskGroup.intro:
Introduction
This collection of cheat sheets will teach you how to use Debrief's Semi Automated Track Construction (SATC) capabilities.
NoPrintTip: If you have multiple monitors, you may wish to drag out this Cheat Sheet window to give you more room for the multiple Debrief windows that you will use later on.NoPrint

task.name: Concepts
task.intro:
Background
Before we get started with loading and manipulating data, we're going to learn some of the background terms and concepts.
task.onCompletion: Ok, that's the boring school work out of the way. The rest of this cheat sheet is all conducted here in Debrief.

taskGroup.name: Single Leg Solution
taskGroup.intro: Introduction The first tutorial in this set will involve an engagement with just a single leg of target data.
taskGroup.onCompletion: And that's the end of the tutorial for single-leg target track construction.

task.name: Generating a project
task.intro: To be able to save your tutorial data, you need a Debrief Workspace to store your data in. But, if you have a Debrief Navigator window open, and in it you can see one or more folders in it, you can skip this step - and move directly to the Generating links... task.
task.onCompletion:
You now have a Debrief Project , to contain your tutorial data.
There are two ways in which we can load sample data. We will be modifying the sample data, so ensure you're not working on data that is shared with other users (the master data). The first thing we need to know is whether your Debrief installation folder is on your local machine or on a Network Shared Folder.
• If it's on a local machine go to Sample Data if Debrief is on a Local Machine
• If it's on a Network Shared Folder, go to Sample Data if Debrief is on a Network Shared Folder.

task.name: Sample data from a local folder
task.intro:
You should have a Debrief project open. You will also need a link to the Debrief sample data. So, open up the projects in your Navigator window, and see if there is a folder titled Sample Data , that contains a folder called SATC . If there is one there, you can skip this task. But, if you don't have a link to the sample data you will have to create one here.
But, how you do that depends on your Debrief installation. If you have Debrief installed on your local machine, then you need to do this set of steps. However, if you run Debrief from a shared network drive, please jump forward to "Sample data from a shared folder".
task.onCompletion: Ok, you've found the Debrief Sample Data. You're ready for the tutorial now.

task.name: Sample Data if Debrief is on a Network Shared Folder
task.intro:
We will now copy in an existing set of sample data from the Debrief\DebriefNG Network Shared Folder.
1. Open the Navigator View
2. Define a project for your work. This is a parent folder where your data (or links to data) is stored. If your Navigator window is empty, refer to the earlier cheat sheet, Generating a project.
Now we will drag in our data:
3. Open Windows Explorer.
4. Arrange your windows so you can see both your sample data folder and Debrief.
5. Drag the sample data folder from Explorer and drop it into Debrief Navigator.
6. A dialog will open asking you if you wish to Copy files and folders or Link to files and folders, select Copy.
task.onCompletion: Great, that's your data now copied in. Now we can move onto the tutorial. Go to Loading a simple scenario.

task.name: Loading the data
task.intro: Let's get some sample data loaded.
task.onCompletion: Ok, now you have ownship track loaded, and you can see the fan of ownship bearing data.

task.name: Creating the scenario
task.intro: Now that data is present, it's time to create a scenario based upon it.
task.onCompletion: We've provided the TMA algortihm with some data, let's see it calculate a solution

task.name: Getting a solution
task.intro: Now for the interesting bit. Let's see SATC generate a solution.
task.onCompletion: We now have a target solution, very close to the truth track, generated by SATC.

task.name: Importing as a TMA track
task.intro: Lastly we're going to import the solution into Debrief as a normal TMA track, for subsequent analysis/exploitation.
task.onCompletion: That's the single leg solution complete, so you can now close this Debrief plot. In the next tutorial, we will look at multi-leg solutions.

taskGroup.intro: In this more advanced multi leg solution, the scenario has several target zigs, and a number of contributions are required to obtain an optimal solution.

And that concludes Debrief's Semi-Automatic Track Construction and the end of this tutorial. Don't forget that we have a comprehensive user manual to help you.
Good luck!
